The vast majority of Poles living in the UK are honest, decent, law-abiding people. But as with everything else in life, there will be exceptions. One of those exceptions is a Polish woman called *Mariola Popko.* She works for a company called *James Gibb Residential Factors,* based in Scotland. A "factor" in Scotland is a property management company (equivalent to Homeowners Association (HOA) in the USA). Popko's job at *James Gibb Residential Factors* is to issue tenants and homeowners with legal threats should they not pay their invoices. Many homeowners/tenants have refused to pay their bills/invoices because they know that these bills are bogus and highly inflated. *James Gibb Factor* forces homeowners/tenants to pay for "services" that have not been rendered and charges them THOUSANDS OF POUNDS just to cut grass and fix fences. JGibb even extorts tenants into paying inflated home insurance. Basically, that is what this company is: extortionists. A criminal outfit masquerading as a respectable company. Just take a look at this https://www.trustpilot.com/review/jamesgibb.co.uk -- THAT is the company that *Mariola Popko* works for. And when a homeowner warned Popko (in an email) that he would expose her criminal conduct (it IS a crime to extort money from people by threatening them with legal repercussions should they not pay these fraudulent bills), the homeowner received an email from a Senior Associate Director of that company, *Marianne Peters,* threatening the homeowner with police action. That is how career criminals do their business. They intimidate those they defraud by trying to turn the tables and making the VICTIMS look like THEY are the criminals. STAY AWAY FROM *JAMES GIBB RESIDENTIAL FACTORS.*   Note that *James Gibb Residential Factors* are owned by a company called *STRATHSPEY CAPITAL* which is headed by a man called *_Stuart Macpherson Pender._* Pender is the person into whose pockets the hard-earned cash of thousands of victims is flowing. https://register.fca.org.uk/s/individual?id=003b000000LUjK0AAL   P.S. Scotland's Housing Minister, Paul McLennan (MSP, i.e., Member of Scottish Parliament) has, in the past, shown an unusual degree of sympathy for this "factor". He was approached by a tenant who felt that he had been cheated by James Gibb Factors out of thousands of pounds over a period of years and he wanted McLennan to do something about it, but McLennan not only rebuffed him but encouraged the tenant to stop pursuing James Gibb Factors, period. How Oliver Crowell was an agent of Amsterdam Jews.  "1643 brought a large contingent of Jews to England, their rallying point was the house of the Portuguese Ambassador De Souza, a Marano (secret Jew). Prominent among them was Fernandez Carvajal, a great financier and army contractor."  In January of the previous year, the attempted arrest of the five members had set in violent motion the armed gangs of "Operatives" already mentioned, from the city. Revolutionary pamphlets were broadcasted on this occasion, as Disraeli tells us: "Bearing the ominous insurrectionary cry of 'To your tents, O Israel'." Shortly after this the King and the Royal Family left the Palace of Whitehall. The five members with armed mobs and banners accompanying them, were given a triumphal return to Westminster. The stage was now set for the advent of Carvajal and his Jews and the rise of their creature Cromwell.  The scene now changes. The Civil War has taken its course. The year is 1647: Naseby has been won and lost. The King is virtually a prisoner, while treated as an honoured guest at Holmby House.  According to a letter published in Plain English on 3rd September, 1921:  "The Learned Elders have been in existence for a much longer period than they have perhaps suspected. My friend, Mr. L. D. van Valckert, of Amsterdam, has recently sent me a letter containing two extracts from the Synagogue at Mulheim. The volume in which they are contained was lost at some period during the Napoleonic Wars, and has recently come into Mr. van Valckert' s possession. It is written in German, and contains extracts of letters sent and received by the authorities of the Mulheim Synagogue. The first entry he sends me is of a letter received:  16th June, 1647. From O.C. (i.e. Oliver Cromwell), by Ebenezer Pratt. "In return for financial support will advocate admission of Jews to England: This however impossible while Charles living.  "Charles cannot be executed without trial, adequate grounds for which do not at present exist. Therefore advise that Charles be assassinated, but will have nothing to do with arrangements for procuring an assassin, though willing to help in his escape.  In reply was dispatched the following:  12th July, 1647. To O.C. by E. Pratt. "Will grant financial aid as soon as Charles removed and Jews admitted. Assassination too dangerous. Charles shall be given opportunity to escape: His recapture will make trial and execution possible. The support will be liberal, but useless to discuss terms until trial commences."  With this information now at our disposal, the subsequent moves on the part of the regicides stand out with a new clearness. On 4th June, 1647, Cornet Joyce, acting on secret orders from Cromwell himself, and, according to Disraeli, unknown even to General-in-Chief Fairfax, descended upon Holmby House with 500 picked revolutionary troopers and seized the King. According to Disraeli,  "The plan was arranged on May 30th at a secret meeting held at Cromwell's house, though later Cromwell pretending that it was without his concurrence."  This move coincided with a sudden development in the army; the rise of the "Levelers" and "Rationalists". Their doctrines were those of the French revolutionaries; in fact, what we know today as Communism. These were the regicides, who four times "purged" Parliament, till there was left finally 50 members, Communist-like themselves, known later as the Rump.

Most people think of the American revolution as a isolated incident. It is not. It has it's roots in the English civil war. Sir Henry Vane Governor of the Massachusetts colony during the English civil war. He wrote a letter to the colony basically saying that the war was not in our interest since it really did not affect the colony and other colonies. His beliefs in a Republican form of government caught on in the colonies leading to the revolution and the founding of the United States. Sir Henry Vane is the founder of the United States. Washington, Jefferson, Madison, Adams, etc. just carried it through.

Dear American Patriots 6/5/24      After many years of coordinating the public reading of our Nationâ€™s Declaration Of Independence from tyrannical rule on Independence Day in Payson Arizonaâ€™s Green Valley Park, I finally leave that role to someone else. Lew Levenson, Bill Sahno, Don and Peri Cline, the homeschooled Marsh siblings who recited from memory the DOI publicly as children, Gary Bedsworth and many others began the annual readings of our Nationâ€™s â€œbirth certificateâ€ on its birthday some 19 years ago.     I typically donated and operated the sound system for the occasion and was eventually asked to take over its annual coordination. That meant enlisting speakers to read 1. The historical context of the Revolutionary war - available online, 2. The actual reading of the DOI - stressing the right and duty of a people to create or alter their government as best suits them, 3. What happened to the 56 Signers (Our nationâ€™s first veterans IMO) once again, available online. 4. Including a Nation Under God theme - as exemplified by the fourth stanza of our 1934 US Congress-approved four verse National Anthem.     Music from a CD of children singing patriotic songs, live electric guitar screaming the anthem in Jimi Hendrix style, live female soloing the fourth verse after the audience singing of the first National Anthem verse, trombone sonorously playing the melody one more time as attendees contemplate our nationâ€™s future and their place in it, audience comments - have all been components at one time or another.    We typically did not seek town sponsorship with its requirement for event insurance coverage or political office-seekers desiring public exposure for the event. It was meant to be a sovereign citizen commemoration without donations, political endorsements or pressures from anything but the universal desire and Creator-endowed right to be free. Perhaps somewhat radical from other average events by todayâ€™s standards.    Hopefully other free persons will energize themselves to hold such Public Readings in their churches, lodges, clubs, taverns, parking lots (shaded, hopefully), parks, event centers and backyards in the future. For therein lies the needed indoctrinating requirement for stiffening patriotic spines everywhere. Therein lie all the reasons for fireworks displays and patriotic music.     Without the Declaration Of Independence as the core of American culture and itâ€™s representative government, it can never hope or claim to be the â€œgreatest nation of the worldâ€ or even provide a glimmer of hope for any global community suffering under the tyranny of despotism anywhere.    Our Declaration Of Independence is the vaccination against all tyranny. Take it, or succumb. Thomas Jefferson said, â€œWhen tyranny becomes law, rebellion becomes duty.â€ And I say, â€œTyranny strives to own every party, group or institution.â€    Become your own private citizen coordinator for such a tyranny-shedding event.    By the way, I challenge you to tally all of the places that publicly read the DOI in this country today. I wager you will feel shame once you try. Youâ€™ve got shoulders. Carry on the tradition of reading the Founding Document publicly. Or history will have but a vague memory of a people who once cherished freedom.    If any wish to contact me for tips or behind-the-scenes assistance, I am at Bruceowales@gmail.com.

It would be a mistake to have an elected head of state. The two kinds of public officials are those who are elected (politicians) and those who are appointed by those who are elected (civil servants). It is the elected who decide public policy because they have the political authority to do so, having been elected by the people. Civil servants, on the other hand, have constitutional powers to implement the policies decided by the elected government, but no political authority/power to decide what those policies will be. It is only the elected who have the power/authority to decide public policy. If a head of state is appointed by the people's elected parliament, that appointed head of state has no political authority/power to decide public policy. That appointed head of state is therefore a civil servant with prescribed duties and no more. If the head of state is elected by the people, that head of state has political authority, having been elected by the people, so can decide public policy and/or refuse to sign into law legislation passed by the houses of parliament. When the President (elected) of the USA does this, they call it a Veto. The US President is a king by another name; and a true monarch in that sense. The Americans made the mistake of having an elected head of state, and look what that has led to. What kind of crazies will get elected down through the years if your head of state is elected? Better to keep all political power and authority in the people's elected parliament, with government by cabinet. It is a mistake to concentrate political power and authority into the hands of just one person. Let a vote of the cabinet decide, not the personal opinion of just one person. And remember, the appointed position of head of state is therefore ceremonial, for fixed periods, and can be downsized to something appropriate. Also, if an appointed head of state is found to be behaving inappropriately, for whatever reason, the people's elected parliament can remove that person from office and replace them.

As contradictory and discordant as it seems, as an American I've always had a soft spot for the Crown, both as an institution itself and the  thousand years of traditions, pomp & ceremony, etc. that it represents.  But I suppose my affinity for the monarchy was attributable to Queen Elizabeth who, having been born in the 1920s, personified the institution and its traditions.  The institution and its wonderfully archaic traditions just seemed "normal" with her on the throne.  You know, people older than the hills doing things the way they were done 100 years ago or more.  But King Charles, well he's a product of my own era (I think Ol' Jug Ears is about ten years older than I am).  To me, seeing him go around in his high-collar tunics, replete with outmoded accoutrements like sword, dirk, etc., festooned with ribbons and medals for battles he never fought, reminds me of a cartoon character out of some Disney production at best, or a flat-out poltroon at worst.  I mean, come on, when was the last time someone went into battler toting a four-foot long sword?  And when did the UK go to war with anyone, aside from Conservatives expressing a divergence of opinion on Covid or immigration policy, in the last 50 years?  Yeah, I'm kinda thinking its time to end it.  The monarchy is an antiquated relic from a bygone era decidedly out of sycnh and in stark contrast with contemporary times.

Sorry for the war a d piece size novel  In 1992, The Queen volunteered to pay income tax and capital gains tax on her personal income, and the King does the same.The two duchies are exempt from corporation tax, but the King and the Prince of Wales voluntarily pay income tax on the revenue they generate. However, the amount of tax they pay is not made public. They do not pay capital gains tax because they do not benefit personally from any increase in the duchies' assets. Members of the Royal Family pay tax on any income generated from privately-owned assets. King Charles does not have to pay inheritance tax on the money he received when Queen Elizabeth died, under the "sovereign to sovereign" exemption agreed in 1993 by then Prime Minister John Major. Some argue that the true cost of the Royal Family is much greater than the size of the Sovereign Grant. It does not cover their security arrangements, which are usually paid for by the Metropolitan Police, although the cost is not disclosed. In May, the Treasury confirmed that Queen Elizabeth II's funeral hadÂ cost the government an estimated Â£162m. It is not yet known what the King's Coronation cost,Â although unofficial estimates suggest it could be between Â£50m and Â£100m. Republic, an organisation which campaigns for an elected head of state, previously estimated that the total yearly cost of the monarchy - once security and other additional costs are factored in -Â is about Â£345m. It is impossible to provide a concrete figure for the scale of the Royal Family's contribution to the UK economy. Estimates vary considerably. The consultancy Brand Finance argues the cost of Royal FamilyÂ is eclipsed by what it contributes by boosting tourism and trade. However,Â Republic questions the validity of its sums,Â and points out that many of the Royal Family's assets are the property of the state. the Sovereign Grant was worth Â£86.3m, the same as in 2021-2022. But repairs to Buckingham Palace -Â which is undergoing a 10-year Â£369m refurbishment planÂ - and the costs associated with King Charles succeeding Queen Elizabeth, plus higher-than-expected inflation, took total spending for the period to Â£107.5m, according to the Royal Household's annual financial report. That representsÂ a 5% increase on the Â£102.4m spent the previous year. The shortfall, with spending greater than the Sovereign Grant, meant drawing Â£20.7m from reserves. The King andÂ other working members of the Royal FamilyÂ use the money to pay for expenses related to their official duties. The vast majority is spent on the upkeep of properties and staff costs. Members of the Royal Family carried out 2,700 engagements across the UK and abroad during the year. More than 95,000 guests attended 330 events at royal residences, including receptions, award investitures and garden parties. Buckingham Palace received more than 183,000 items  The Royal Family was previously funded through a fixed annual payment known as the Civil List. This was replaced by the Sovereign Grant in 2012. Profits of the Crown Estate - a property business owned by the monarch but run independently - go to the Treasury. The level of profit is used as a benchmark to calculate the funding given by the government to the Royal Family. The Crown Estate had assets worth Â£16.5bn in 2022: almost Â£8bn of properties in London, including Regent Street, as well as nearly half the land along the coast of England, Wales and Northern Ireland. It is not the King's private property - it merely belongs to the monarch for the duration of their reign. The King cannot sell its assets or keep any profits for himself. The Sovereign Grant had been worth 15% of the Crown Estate profits generated two years previously. In 2017 it was agreed thatÂ this would increase to 25%Â for 10 years to help pay for the Buckingham Palace repairs. After a review,Â the government announced the Sovereign Grant will be worth 12% of the Crown Estate's profits from next year. The decision follows a significant increase in profits from six new offshore wind farms on the Crown Estate, worth Â£1bn. In January, King Charles said he wanted the extra profitsÂ to be used for the "wider public good". Cutting the percentage will mean the total Sovereign Grant for 2024-25 will remain at Â£86.3m for the third consecutive year. However, if Crown Estate profits grow as predicted, even under the reduced formula, the amount given to the Royal Family would then increase substantially, to Â£124.8m in 2025-2026 and Â£126m in 2026-2027. The 12% figure is due to remain in place until the end of the 10-year Buckingham Palace restoration project in 2027.   The King also receives moneyÂ from a private estate called the Duchy of Lancaster,Â which is passed down from monarch to monarch. It covers more than 18,000 hectares of land in areas such as Lancashire and Yorkshire, as well as property in central London. Worth Â£654m, it generates about Â£20m a year in profits. Whoever holds the title of Duke of Cornwall (currently Prince William)Â benefits from the Duchy of Cornwall. It mainly covers land in south-west England. Worth Â£1bn, it generated a net surplus of Â£24m in 2022-23. The King and Prince William receive the profits from the duchies personally, and can spend them as they wish. However, they are not entitled to any proceeds from the sale of any estate assets, which must be reinvested. The monarch also owns the royal palaces (which are not part of the Crown Estate) and part of the Royal Collection of art, but these do not generate income. Some palaces are looked after and funded by the Royal Family itself. Others - such as the Tower of London - are managed by Historic Royal Palaces, an independent charity. The Royal Collection is also run by a charity, the Royal Collection Trust, which reinvests income received from ticket sales and retail outlets. The King also privately owns properties such as Sandringham and Balmoral. In addition, some Royal Family members have private art, jewellery and stamp collections which they can sell or use to generate income as they wish.

The King is the UK head of state, but his powers are largely symbolic and ceremonial. He remains politically neutral.  However- Appointing a government - the leader of the party that wins a general election is usually called to Buckingham Palace, where they are invited to form a government. The King also formally dissolves Parliament before a general election     State Opening and the King's Speech - the King sets out the government's plans in a speech delivered from the throne in the House of Lords     Royal Assent - when a piece of legislation is passed through Parliament, it must be formally approved by the King in order to become law. The last time Royal Assent was refused was in 1708

As a young lad our whole school was turned out to line the pathways so that The Queen could cut a ribbon to open a new factory. It was pissing down with rain, freezing and a wind was howling that nearly took us off our feet. I was only 12 or 13. We waited for their arrival, and waited, and waited - after about 45 mins her car sped past so fast that I didn't even get its colour! Could we go back to school? No we had to wait there for her exit back to Holyrood Palace. After about another 45 mins we went back to school as she never appeared - there was a quicker way back to the Palace than the way she had come. My only though was- "what is all this bollocks?". It still is.

Unfortunately, Double Down confuses two things; Charles Windsor and his family, and King Charles III. Charles Windsor is a person, and King Charles III is a part of the Constitution. Presumably he wants to abolish the monarchy, and not abolish Charles Windsor, which would be murder.  Removing the monarchy, i.e changing the Constitution, is a big thing, probably bigger or as big as Brexit,  and cannot be done lightly, especially as it involves the whole mechanism of Government. Any replacement is going to be costly, as any President is going to require all the trappings of an Head of State; good salary, nice house and all the perks plus the ceremonies, whatever they should be. However, very few people will want to travel to the UK to see the President, so it will be all cost. A change of Constitution has got to be shown to be an improvement and worth the cost.   Charles Windsor and his extended family, will have to be retired, and I hope that no one is stupid enough to suggest any punishment. This will be a cost, but reducing over time presumably. There is plenty of good examples in the world.  So in summary, we will require a Referendum to decide to change the Constitution. If successful, then somebody has got to draw up a new Constitution and have it approved by Parliament and the People, ie. a second Referendum. then we'll have to implement the new Constitution; i.e. probably vote for a President and an elected House of 'Lords'. There will be hardly any, if any,  savings available to finance the NHS, or other good causes. ( Â£100 million is only Â£1.50/person in the UK, ignoring any foreign countries that our monarch rules over )  And after all of that we'll probably finish up with some arrogant , pompous, grubby  politician, like all the other Presidents in the world. Just look at Sadiq Khan, Nicola Sturgeon, Emmanuel Macron, etc.

I support your viewpoint about the parasites sitting on their thrones in Britain wholeheartedly.  When I was 8 yrs. old the newly crowned Elizabeth and her sidekick Philip came to our town to visit the Battlefield Monument, erected in Stoney Creek, Ontario to celebrate the British winning the War of 1812 over the American invaders. Our whole public school, from grades 1 to 8, were taught to bow and curtsy beforehand.  As her convertible came up the drive with Elizabeth and Philip seated in it, all of us school children bowed and curtsied to them, all except me that is.  Philip stood up when he saw me standing there so I gave a quick bob in their direction, having made my point.   My dad had been a WWII veteran, but also French Acadian by birth, so I grew up listening to stories about the Great Expulsion of 1755 at Grand Pre, N.S.  The British soldiers forced the Acadian people into boats, thereby separating families from one another. never to be reunited again.  My dad had to fight under the British flag in WWII, as Canada didn't even have its own flag at the time. The serious character flaws and poor judgment of Charles Windsor, the recently-ascended British monarch, would in any fair and objective consideration have disqualified him from appointment to any public office, let alone that of Head of State. However the more important question to be asked is not about the acceptability of this or that individual, but about the monarchical system itself. Monarchy, in Britain and elsewhere in the modern world where it persists, is an anachronistic and by its very nature profoundly antidemocratic institution. Whether in its absolutist or constitutional form it is the ultimate glorification of privilege and inequality and functions as an ideological legitimation for other political, cultural and economic structures that also perpetrate and perpetuate these vices. Sadly, much of the population remains in thrall to monarchy's irrationality, conceits and deceits, as they do to those of the complementary and mutually reinforcing institution of religion (whose pre-eminent voice in England continues to be the established Church of England).  Harry Windsor and Meghan Markle's recent distancing of themselves from the status quo, though limited and clearly motivated by negative personal experience, is to their credit so far as it goes (not *_very_* far). But it will be a great deal more to their credit if they should ever find the clarity of vision to see beyond their own tedious individual circumstances and the strength of conviction to break completely with the monarchy and actively work for its dissolution. And the same goes for all of us.

He died a martyr to the cause. "The English Civil Wars comprised three wars, which were fought between Charles I and Parliament between 1642 and 1651. The wars were part of a wider conflict involving Wales, Scotland and Ireland, known as the Wars of the Three Kingdoms." Here is an extract, "In 1645, Parliament reaffirmed its determination to fight the war to a finish. It passed the Self-denying Ordinance, by which all members of either House of Parliament laid down their commands and re-organized its main forces into the New Model Army, under the command of Sir Thomas Fairfax, with Cromwell as his second-in-command and Lieutenant-General of Horse. In two decisive engagements â€“ the Battle of Naseby on 14 June and the Battle of Langport on 10 July â€“ the Parliamentarians effectively destroyed Charles's armies.   In the remains of his English realm, Charles tried to recover a stable base of support by consolidating the Midlands. He began to form an axis between Oxford and Newark-on-Trent in Nottinghamshire. These towns had become fortresses and showed more reliable loyalty to him than others. He took Leicester, which lies between them, but found his resources exhausted. Having little opportunity to replenish them, in May 1646 he sought shelter with a Presbyterian Scottish army at Southwell in Nottinghamshire. Charles was eventually handed over to the English Parliament by the Scots and imprisoned. This marked the end of the First English Civil War. However, skipping a bit!!!...  In the North of England, Major-General John Lambert fought a successful campaign against several Royalist uprisings, the largest being that of Sir Marmaduke Langdale in Cumberland. Thanks to Lambert's successes, the Scottish commander, the Duke of Hamilton, had to take a western route through Carlisle in his pro-Royalist Scottish invasion of England.The Parliamentarians under Cromwell engaged the Scots at the Battle of Preston (17â€“19 August). The battle took place largely at Walton-le-Dale near Preston, Lancashire, and resulted in a victory for Cromwell's troops over the Royalists and Scots commanded by Hamilton.This victory marked the end of the Second English Civil War. Third English Civil War (1649â€“1651) well that was nothing to do with King Charles the 1st. He was no longer about. They murdered him after an unfair trial, that in my opion he shouldnt have bothered attending as he was King after all.  Nonetheless, we move on...  Cromwellian conquest of Ireland. Ireland had undergone continual war since the rebellion of 1641, with most of the island controlled by the Irish Confederates. Increasingly threatened by the armies of the English Parliament after Charles I's arrest in 1648, the Confederates signed a treaty of alliance with the English Royalists. The joint Royalist and Confederate forces under the Duke of Ormonde tried to eliminate the Parliamentary army holding Dublin by laying siege, but their opponents routed them at the Battle of Rathmines (2 August 1649). As the former Member of Parliament Admiral Robert Blake blockaded Prince Rupert's fleet in Kinsale, Cromwell could land at Dublin on 15 August 1649 with an army to quell the Royalist alliance.  Cromwell's suppression of the Royalists in Ireland in 1649 is still remembered by many Irish people. After the Siege of Drogheda, the massacre of nearly 3,500 people â€“ around 2,700 Royalist soldiers and 700 others, including civilians, prisoners and Catholic priests (Cromwell claimed all had carried arms) â€“ became one of the historical memories that has driven Irish-English and Catholic-Protestant strife during the last three centuries. The Parliamentarian conquest of Ireland ground on for another four years until 1653, when the last Irish Confederate and Royalist troops surrendered. In the wake of the conquest, the victors confiscated almost all Irish Catholic-owned land and distributed it to Parliament's creditors, to Parliamentary soldiers who served in Ireland, and to English who had settled there before the war. The 100M pounds spent on the coronation was a good thing for Britain. People got paid, British companies got paid. Although in some theoretical sense, the money could have been used for pay rises for nurses or whatever, the reality is that it wouldn't have been. Even if it had, it wouldn't have gone far. All the overseas guests at the coronation (and the Queen's funeral) paid for themselves, bringing money into the U.K. You ask what does the monarchy actually do? We don't know in detail, but the monarch does do a lot of soft diplomacy with overseas countries, helping to bring money into the U.K. economy. Whether that might involve selling British made arms to be used in foreign wars, I don't know.

This gives the King (with his advisors);  [a] a longer time-frame to put in place the required actions to improve the lives of his citizens, [b] the ability to hold public referendums regarding any major new bills and laws, and [c] the motivation/incentive to actually do a good job, or he will lose his privileged position and have to reap the punishing consequences of his careless, detrimental or damaging actions, by - instead of beheading - financial penalties or prison time! There are good traditions and not so good traditions. One tradition worth keeping is the Monarchy. There are many reasons, but here is one for you to think about. Did you know the Nazis came to power through democratic elections? The Nazis won the largest number of seats and Hitler became Chancellor through a coalition. However after a fire in the Reichstag Hitler was able to persuade the President to pass first of all a decree suspending civil liberties, which allowed Hitler to ban the communist party, his chief opposition. Then he later persuaded Hindenburg (the President) to pass the Enabling Act, which effectively suspended the German constitution and allowed to rule without passing legislation by the Reichstag.  It occurred to me then, that this could not have happened in Britain. With the possible exception of Edward VIII, I cannot see any of the British monarchs (of the 20th and 21st centuries) agreeing to sign off on any law or decree that would have allowed a British PM to have overturn the British constitution and rule in an authoritarian way. In my view monarchy is an essential part of the British constitution that is a bulwark against authoritarianism.

Ignorant manğŸ˜±  The inauguration of a Head of State is a costly affair whether that Head of State be the President of a Republic or a Monarch of a Kingdom. ALL such ceremonies and celebrations are State occasions and paid for by the Government of each country. For the inauguration of a US President, the cost is anywhere between US$100m to US$200m or Â£80m to Â£160m and that cost is repeated EVERY 4 years. So, using the reign of our beloved late Queen Elizabeth I of 70 years, the cost to the US taxpayers for 18 Inaugurations would have been '''US$1.8 billion to US$3.66 billion or Â£1.44 billion to Â£2.88 billion. Economic increased activity to the USA due to a Presidential inauguration ... next to nothing over the same 70 years. For the Coronation of King Charles Ill of the United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland, the cost is projected to be Â£100m. We are ALL better served by a Constitutional Monarch than an elected nobody.  Who is the Head if State of Germany, Eire or Italy - and I don't mean the Prime Minister, Taoiseach or Chancellor?   And what if, by popular mandate, a Boris Johnson, Jimmy Savile, or a Vladimir Putin were to be elected as President of the United (not Kingdom) of Great (really?) Britain and Northern Ireland?  It's now estimated that over Â£1 billion has already been generated for the UK by the Coronation - that's a decent payback.  So I'd rather have an imperfect but benevolent Monarch with no constitutional power, who recycles everything (including the coronation robes, chairs and flags) and hates central heating, than see a President Fat Cat ex Politician being driven to his or her "enthronement" in a bomb proof limo accompanied by 20 armoured police cars plus 30 outriders.  Besides, the newly installed President would hardly live in a townhouse in Mayfair, and judging by the tastes and habits of other Heads of State, they tend to like living in the odd Palace or five.  And if the Monarch were to be displaced, then no doubt there would be a huge furore about the legal reversion of the entire Crown Estate.  Or would you prefer to confiscate everything and throw the entire Royal Family into the Tower?  Or exile them to the Isle of Elba?  Or chop their heads off?   Think about the consequences before ranting republican bile, because no matter how much you dislike "privilige" and pageantry, I'd rather see my Head of State receive the King of Spain with appropriate protocol and in corresponding dignity, just as we'd expect our Head of State to be honoured overseas.  After all, status, pomp and dignity go hand in hand, the UK is the world lead in ceremony (like it or not, and if so, look the other way)   Some ex pop star in a wig and purple glasses might not fit the bill, no matter how popular a singer he or she might be. I don't really care if we keep it or ditch it since im apolitical. But I don't agree in regards to the English Civil war. That event isn't a revolution like the French revolution or the American Revolution. The English civil war was a war about religious division not, republican ideals. I have no idea why Republicans like to cite that historical event to match with their views. The King was not executed because the principle or concept of a hereditary monarch was ludicrous, or people were starting to realise, or wake up or anything. It was in regards of matters over the church of England and religious division. Cromwell wanted a strict puritian state. And the king was clearly sympathetic to catholic sentiments and had constantly made mistake after mistake especially in regard to Scotland. The parliamentarians did not want to get rid of the king initially. They just wanted him controlled. They even offered to make Cromwell a king. But cromwell preferred his title as lord protector and he passed it onto his son. So even cromwell was still trying to create some form of a hereditary monarch. The rump was a half assed version of a republic. So although that event has elements of a republic they are entirely unintentional. The civil war was another war defined by the roots of religious intolerance and division. While those other events like the American revolution and french revolution were in response to inequality and a want for freedom against a governing system they oppose and it involved the people. English civil war was still limited to a particular class of people of, parliamentarians vs the royalists.

You have in Britain a long proud tradition of stability second to none largely because of the continuity of the monarchy as part of a set of institutions which balance each other in their roles of state - it is naive to think that directly elected heads of state are a better option since it permits the office of state to be open to the forces of corruption - the UK is almost uniquely shielded from this because of the crown's impartiality - and the current system makes it virtually impossible for tyranny to occur. The monarch is steeped in the traditions and values the position embodies. Finally it should be remembered that even kings and queens must govern with the consent of the people which is why the monarchy is constantly trying to make itself relevant. The Crown is a symbol embodied by a person, when you swear allegiance to the King you are swearing to the Crown and all it symbolises. If you think that turning palaces into public parks and having an elected head of state will enhance the lives of ordinary people then you have failed to notice how the lot of ordinary people in countries with elected heads of state are often much worse - I should know I live in one of them, one of the oldest and most corrupt democracies in the world in fact: Greece

Does anyone have an Idea how many royal titles their could be if the law was changed in the USA?    In the United States, the Constitution prohibits the granting of titles of nobility by the federal and state governments. This means that any attempt to change the law to allow for royal titles would require a constitutional amendment.  However, if such a change were to occur, there are many possible royal titles that could be created. Some options include:  King/Queen: The most obvious royal title would be that of King or Queen. This title has been used throughout history in many different cultures and could easily be adapted for use in the United States.  Duke/Duchess: A Duke or Duchess is a noble title that is typically given to a member of the royal family who is not in direct line for the throne. This could be a good option for members of the extended royal family.  Prince/Princess: The title of Prince or Princess is typically given to the children of a monarch. In the United States, this title could be given to the children of the President or other high-ranking government officials.  Earl/Countess: The title of Earl or Countess is a noble title that is below that of Duke but above that of Viscount. This could be a good option for members of the royal family who are not in direct line for the throne.  Baron/Baroness: The title of Baron or Baroness is a noble title that is below that of Earl. This title could be given to members of the royal family or to individuals who have made significant contributions to society.  Viscount/Viscountess: The title of Viscount or Viscountess is a noble title that is below that of Earl but above that of Baron. This title could be given to members of the royal family or to individuals who have made significant contributions to society.  It's important to note that any change to the law regarding the granting of royal titles would be a significant departure from the current political and social structure in the United States, and it's unclear whether such a change would be widely accepted or welcomed by the American public.

So, this may be the last.  William was not raised from birth to value such things.  Charles grew up under the wing of his grandmother, the Queen-Mum. I am no supporter of the Royal family, at all, but you seem very confused regarding the role of the Monarch and the role of the Government. Your attribution of the royals as "gangsters" might well have been true in Plantagenet, Tudor and Stuart times but George I was brought in by the British parliament of the time to avoid a catholic monarch, he was such a distant relative of the preceding monarchy that he was barely in line at all. He was given a very strict brief by Parliament about what he could and could not do. Any subsequent "gangsterism" is really down to our governments, elected governments mind you, since that time. I agree it looks "silly" to see royals adorned by so many medals they could not have possibly have earned but surely this is just pageantry, or even pantomime, I am surprised if anyone in the country looks on thinking they are heroes? The cost of the coronation is ridiculous given the nation's finances BUT this is a government spending decision not one of Charles. The royals do sell arms to other countries but at the behest of the government, yeah I bet they make money on the side in these and similar ventures but our government, of whatever colour, has wheeled them out to play. I also strongly suspect that when these regimental "heads" go out and chat with squaddies it is the latter who enjoy the interaction the most, I doubt it is more than a chore for the royals. Perhaps, the squaddies are similarly bored, I know I would not be interested, but I suspect there must be a large enough pool of interested squaddies so that the uninterested are not compelled to take part. For reasons that escape me there are still many people in the country who do admire the royal family, not hard to spot them. Certainly many deserving recipients of national awards are pleased to be celebrated in the pageantry of palace and ceremony - more so than they would be to receive their award from President Kinnock or President Boris-Johnson's-Dad or who ever. I don't refer to the Party awards to pay off political donors but the nurses  and lollipop men/women who have gone the extra mile to help their communities and folk like them. I don't care for the royals but I don't feel responsible for them either, we just get the next one in the queue. In a parliamentary democracy without a constitutional monarch then President Boris-Johnson's-Dad type heads of state are something of an inevitability - and be assured they will also want to play expensive dressing up games.

Again, not saying not to do it, but I am saying if it was abolished tomorrow, the way things are today, nothing would change.

There were 3 main armies in the English Civil wars. You mention all 3 yet state that there were only 2 armies â€“ why? The armies were Parliament, King & Levellers.   The Levellers, as you say, represented the common people.  We lost.   Did it make any difference that Parliament beat the Crown & beheaded the King in 1649? Parliament were the landowners, the ones who meted out the day-to-day atrocities under Monarchy so did people see any difference in their lived experience? Probably not. Did the Restoration of the Monarchy in 1660 make any difference? Maybe a little, maybe a slight improvement but probably not for most.  You also fail to note the big Constitutional change, the Bill of Rights of 1688, the settlement that handed essentially all power to Parliament. Monarchs do what they are told, meet who they are told to meet where & when they are told to meet them. Monarchs are tools of Parliament.
